command.name: commandname
command.syntax:
syntax of the command
askfile "TITLE DIALOG-TYPE FILE-MASKS
DEF-DIR DEF-EXT FILE-ALIAS"
Title Title of dialog box
TeX and LaTeX
Troff
Lout
File-alias alias to put filename in blah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blah blah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blah blah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blah blah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blah
command.long: long description blah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blah blah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blah blah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blah blah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blahblah blah
command.notes: general notes note1 DO NOT note2 dO THIS

command.name: help
command.long: This command shows help on the available commands. Help without a command shows a list of all valid commands. Help with a command shows help on that command.

command.name: showkeybnf
command.short: Show the Bachus Nauer Form of Key format
command.long: This command shows the Bachus Nauer Form of the Key format.

command.name: setalias
command.long: Creates an internal alias "aliasname" with value "string"
command.notes: general notes String can contain reference to other aliases and environment variables.

command.name: setenv
command.long: Creates an environment-variable "env-name" with value "string"
command.notes:
general notes
The environment, from which the program was started, is only modified during execution.
String can contain reference to other aliases and environment variables.

command.name: showalias
command.long: The showalias command, without an alias(name), shows all defined aliases. The showalias command with a name shows that alias.

command.name: showenv
command.long: The showenv command shows the contents of the "environment_variable" variable.
command.notes: general notes Environment variables MUST be typed in CAPITAL letters.

command.name: %{} OR %alias
command.long: Substitutes the internal alias "aliasname" with a string assigned earlier to this alias.
command.notes: general notes Environment variables MUST be typed in CAPITAL letters.

command.name: ${} OR $envvariable
command.long: Substitutes environment-variable "envname" with the stored string
command.notes: general notes An environment variable can contain an empty string, but the variable MUST exist.

command.name: askfile

syntax.simpara: Dialog-type Type of dialog box (OPEN or SAVE)
File-alias alias to put filename in

command.long: Shows a dialog, with drive, directory and file boxes, to select or enter a file. For the selected file an alias is created (<File-alias>) containing the file name. This mechanism is used to be able to load or save the file from a process file by using the alias.
command.notes:
general notes
Double-quotes are optional, use them when your string contains special characters, such as ';' (end of command)

example.simpara: askfile "Open GDS-II file OPEN GDS-II|*.gds;*.cal|All|*.*| C:\DATA\ CAL selectedfile"

command.name: ask

syntax.simpara: Title Title of the input dialog
Alias alias to put the input into File-alias alias to put filename in

command.long: Asks for input string to the user, the result will be set as an alias

example.simpara: ask "Please give me some input" myaliasvar

command.name: showfilename
command.long: output as a message the file that is currently in memory

command.name: savevisible
command.long: Only the layers that are visible on the screen will be saved to a file e.g. GDSII or KEY etc, when using the savefile command.
command.notes:
general notes
When writing to a file, the current file remains in memory, to prevent data-loss.

command.name: savefile

syntax.simpara: Filename Path + name of the file
Filetype Type of file (gds-ii, key or flash)

command.long: Save a file to a certain type.
command.notes:
general notes
File type must be specified at all times. The extension can be anything at all.

command.name: loadfile

syntax.simpara: Filename Path + name of the file
Filetype Type of file (gds-ii, key or flash)

command.long: Load a file of a certain type.
command.notes:
general notes
File type must be specified at all times. The extension can be anything at all.

command.name: mergefile

syntax.simpara: Filename Path + name of the file
Filetype Type of file (gds-ii, key or flash)

command.short: Loads a file and merges it with the one in memory
command.long: Loads a file of the given type and merges it with the one in memory
command.notes:
general notes
File type must be specified at all times. The extension can be anything at all. This operation is only available when a file is in memory.

command.name: closefile
command.long: Close the current (data)file in memory
command.notes:
general notes
Changes will be lost, use command savefile to save first

command.name: loadsetup
command.short: Load a setup or configuration file
command.long: Load a setup or configuration file. A setup file is not different from a process file. So it just contains a set of commands. But in this case it more meant for setting layers and factors for the program. Several setupfiles can exist, during startup the $HOME/gdsuser/config/user.set will always be used. Or if not available $GDSROOT/default/config/default.set.
command.notes:
general notes
On closing the application, the current settings will be saved. This can be overruled by the command savesetuponexit

command.name: savesetup
command.short: Save a setup or configuration file
command.long: Save a setup or configuration file. A setup file is not different from a process file. So it just contains a set of commands. But in this case it more meant for setting layers and factors for the program. Several setupfiles can exist, during startup the $HOME/gdsuser/config/user.set will always be used. Or if not available $GDSROOT/default/config/default.set.
command.notes:
general notes
On closing the application, the current settings will be saved. This can be overruled by the command savesetuponexit

command.name: loadprocess
command.short: Execute a processing file. This is a file containing pre-recorded commands and can be used as a macro.
command.long: Execute a processing file. This is a file containing pre-recorded commands and can be used as a macro.
command.notes:
general notes
Settings may/can be changed during execution.

command.name: record
command.long: Start/Stop process recording. This function is used to record a macro file. While recording all (executed) actions are recorded to the file. When executing a process file, the record command will be ignored.
command.notes:
general notes
This function overwrites an existing file (if it can).

command.name: keystring
command.short: For drawing using a key file string. Handy in process files.
command.long: For drawing using a key file string. Handy in process files.
command.notes:
general notes
Only the elements from Key files can be used inside a key string. The key elements are seperated by a semi-colon or a backslash character to continue on the next line.

command.name: defaultaccur
command.long: Sets the default accuracy. This is used when a process file with key strings is read. When a file is in memory, the accuracy from that file is used. If not, the accuracy 'defaultaccur' will be used. Using a value of 0.01 means that two figures behind the comma will be displayed.
command.notes:
general notes
This value is only used when there's no file in memory.

command.name: defaultunit

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: Sets the default unit. This is used when a process file with key strings is read. The numbers in the file will be interpreted with 'defaultunit' as multiplier instead of meters (=1).

command.name: selected
command.long: When selected 1, the operations which don't need groups are performed only on selected elements in layers.

command.name: selectmarge
command.long: The purpose of 'selectmarge' is that a user doesn't have to click exactly on a polygon to select it. 'Selectmarge' defines the percentage of the screenwidth a user can click next to a polygon and still select it.

command.name: snapfactor

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: At the beginning of a logical operation (i.e. AND, OR...) polygon segments shorter than 'snapfactor' are removed. Polygons that are closer to eachother than 'snapfactor' are connected to eachother.

command.name: correctionfactor

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used by the correction and makering functions, which create a ring around the polygons. For correction, this factor determines the width by which the polygon is enlarged or shrinked. A positive correctionfactor enlarges the polygon and a negative shrinks it. For makering, this factor determines half the width (radius) of the ring. The boundaries of the ring are this size smaller and larger than the original polygon.

command.name: correctionaber

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used when creating a ring around the boundaries of a polygon. It determines the accuracy of the segments of the ring.

command.name: roundfactor
command.long: This variable is used when rounding sharp corners. An arc is calculated at the sharp edge of a polygon. If the distance of the sharp edge to the midpoint of arc is longer than arc-radius * roundfactor, then the edge is replaced by the arc.

command.name: roundtype
command.long: This variable specifies the rounding type when creating a ring around a sharp edge. The rounding type is used when the distance of the new edge to the original is longer than 'roundfactor' * 'correctionfactor'. The circles must fit inside the enlarged/shrinked polygon. The Circle type creates a circle with the old edge as midpoint and 'correctionfactor' as radius. The Medial type creates a circle on the line between the old and new edge. The far most crossing of this circle with this help-line is laying at a distance of 'roundfactor' * 'correctionfactor' from the old edge.
command.notes:
general notes
NOT IMPLEMENTED YET Only Circle type is used !.

command.name: toarcrmin

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used by the polygon to arc conversion function, and specifies the minimum radius of an arc.

command.name: toarcrmax

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used by the polygon to arc conversion function, and specifies the maximum radius of an arc.

command.name: arcaccur

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used by the polygon to arc conversion function, and specifies the maximum abberation of an arc to the original line-pieces.

command.name: polyaccur

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used by the arc/circle to polygon conversion function, and specifies the maximum abberation of a polygon to the original arc/circle.

command.name: smoothaccur

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used by the smoothen function, and specifies the maximum abberation the new polygon may have to the original.

command.name: maxlinemerge

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used by the smoothen function, and specifies the maximum length of a line-pieces where other lines may be merged to.

command.name: displayaber

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: This variable is used by the screendriver, and specifies the accuracy of displayed arcs and circles. Internally they are converted to line-pieces. This variable is the display version of 'polyaccur', which is the operation version. Too see the effect of a change in value, redraw the screen.

command.name: structhres
command.long: This variable is used by the screendriver, and specifies when a structure will be drawn. If the structure boundingbox on the screen is less then the given number of pixels on the screen, only the boundingbox will be drawn. For huge drawings this will increase the drawing speed.

command.name: primthres
command.long: This variable is used by the screendriver, and specifies when a primitive will be drawn. If the primitive boundingbox on the screen is less then the given number of pixels on the screen, only the boundingbox will be drawn if the second parameter is True. If the second parameter is False nothing will be drawn. For huge drawings this will increase the drawing speed.

command.name: mirrorx
command.long: Mirrorx sets the option for the transform and transform_a operations to mirror selected elements in the X-axis.

command.name: mirrory
command.long: Mirrory sets the option for the transform and transform_a operations to mirror selected elements in the Y-axis.

command.name: movehor

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: Specifies the distance structures are moved horizontal when the transform or transform_a operation is performed.

command.name: movever

syntax.simpara: <unit> in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: Specifies the distance structures are moved vertical when the transform or transform_a operation is performed.

command.name: scale
command.long: Specifies the scale factor for the transform and transform_a operations.

command.name: rotate
command.long: Specifies the rotation in degrees for the transform and transform_a operations.

command.name: direction
command.long: Specifies the direction of the rotation for the transform and transform_a operations.

command.name: showgroupsdlg
command.short: Show group settings dialog (A, B and Destination)
command.long: Groups are used for several operations, like boolean operations. Shows the layers in group A, B and destination. Groups A and B contains a list of layernumbers, destination contains only one layer. You can set if the element in the ayers in the groups should be only selected elements or all. For the destination you can select either add to the destination or overwrite what is on that layer.

command.name: group_a

syntax.simpara: to set group_a to (selected) elements on given layers: group_a <layer_no> <layer_no> <layer_no> {True|False}
if True is set, only selected elements in the layers will be used.
to set group_a to the selected elements in the drawing:

command.long: Fill/clear layer-group A

command.name: group_b

syntax.simpara: to set group_b to (selected) elements on given layers: group_a <layer_no> <layer_no> <layer_no> {True|False}
if True is set, only selected elements in the layers will be used.
to set group_b to the selected elements in the drawing:

command.long: Fill/clear layer-group B

command.name: destination

syntax.simpara: True means add result to this layer, else overwrite the destination layer.

command.long: Set destination layer for output of operations on layers.

command.name: flatten {one}
command.long: The datafile can consist of several structures and structure-references. Flatten expands all references in the visible structure to one (top)structure by copying the elements inside referenced structures to that level. Empty structures will be removed. If the selected flag is set, only selected elements will be flattened. "flatten one", Only removes one level of hierarchy.

notes.note: File may grow very large (in memory too)

command.name: delete
command.long: Deletes in Visible structure contents, elements that are selected or all, depending if flag "selected" is set.

notes.note: Only the elements inside the visible top structure are deleted. Selected References are also deleted, by first exploded to make them unique. This may lead to empty structures.

command.name: delete_a
command.long: Deletes in visible structure contents, elements specified in group A. Group A is specified with the group_a command. In case the onlyselected flag is set for group A, selected References are first exploded. The command only deletes elements,this may result in empty structures

notes.note: A must be set. B and destination are ignored.
Only the elements inside the visible structure are deleted, references to other structures will be exploded first if onlyselected in the group is True.

command.name: transform
command.short: Transforms structure contents visible on screen.
command.long: Transforms structure contents visible on screen. Uses the transformation settings.

notes.note: Transformation can be undone with undotrans. Selected flag can be set to transform only the selected elements (also structure references)

command.name: undotrans
command.long: Transforms elements back to old situation (before last transform).

notes.note: Transformation can only be undone immediately after the transformation itself. When first an other command is chosen, 'undotrans' becomes unavailable.

command.name: transform_a
command.long: Transforms in visible structure contents elements specified in group A. Uses the transformation settings.

notes.note: A must be set. B and destination are ignored
Transformation can be undone with undotrans_a.

command.name: undotrans_a
command.long: Transforms elements back to old situation (before last transform).

notes.note: Transformation can only be undone immediately after the transformation itself. When first an other command is chosen, 'undotrans' becomes unavailable.

command.name: makering
command.short: Creates a ring around filled elements
command.long: Creates a ring around the boundaries of elements defined in group A.

notes.note: A and Desination set. B is ignored.
All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)

command.name: correction
command.short: Creates a ring around filled elements
command.long: Creates a ring around the boundaries of elements defined in group A. And merges it with the original polygons. With a positive/negetive correction value you can enlarge/shrink the drawing with that value.

notes.note: A and Desination set. B is ignored.
All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)

command.name: copy_a
command.short: Duplicates elements from group A to the layer in destination.
command.long: Duplicates elements from group A to the layer in destination.

notes.note: A and Desination set. B is ignored.

command.name: move_a
command.short: Changes the layer-numbers of the elements in group A to the layer in destination.
command.long: Changes the layer-numbers of the elements in group A to the layer in destination.

notes.note: A and Desination set. B is ignored.

command.name: toarcs
command.long: Detects arcs in polygons and replaces those with segments. 'toarcrmax' and 'toarcrmin' as range for the radius. 'arcaccur' for maximum abberation between the arc and the polygon segments.

notes.note: A and Desination set. B is ignored.

command.name: tolines
command.short: Convert arcs and circles to polygons.
command.long: Replaces arcs and circles, in a polygon, with line-pieces. 'polyaccur' determines the maximum abberation that between the polygon segments and the arc/circle.

notes.note: All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)
A and Desination set. B is ignored.

command.name: smoothen
command.short: Removes glitches and short lines from polygons.
command.long: Removes glitches and short lines from polygons. Uses 'smoothaccur' for maximum abberation of the smoothed polygon-segments to the originals. Uses 'maxlinemerge' for maximum line-length to merge lines to.

notes.note: A and Desination set. B is ignored.
All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. Polylines and polygons containing arcsegments are also converted. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)

command.name: intersect
command.short: Calculate intersections (Logical AND: A AND B)
command.long: Calculate the intersections (overlappings) between the elements in group A and B. 'snapfactor' determines the accuracy with which the calculations are performed, and 'polyaccur' for conversion of Arcs and Circles.

notes.note: A or B and destination must be set.
All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)

command.name: merge
command.short: Merges elements (Logical OR: A OR B)
command.long: Merges the elements in group A and B (Logical OR of A and B) 'snapfactor' determines the accuracy with which the calculations are performed, and 'polyaccur' for conversion of Arcs and Circles.

notes.note: A or B and destination must be set.
All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)

command.name: a_subtract_b
command.long: Subtracts the contents of group B from those of group A (A-B). 'snapfactor' determines the accuracy with which the calculations are performed, and 'polyaccur' for conversion of Arcs and Circles.

notes.note: A or B and destination must be set.
All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)

command.name: b_subtract_a
command.long: Subtracts the contents of group A from those of group B (B-A). 'snapfactor' determines the accuracy with which the calculations are performed, and 'polyaccur' for conversion of Arcs and Circles.

notes.note: A or B and destination must be set.
All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)

command.name: exor
command.long: Exor (Logical EXOR: A EXOR B) Performs an exclusive-or operation between the contents of group A and B. This results in the differences between group A and B (i.e. overlappings are not copied). 'snapfactor' determines the accuracy with which the calculations are performed, and 'polyaccur' for conversion of Arcs and Circles.

notes.note: A or B and destination must be set.
All elements that have a surface are converted to polygons. (Text does not have a surface and is not converted.)

command.name: showlayerdlg
command.long: Show the layers settings dialog, which can be used to set the layer settings.

command.name: setlayer
command.long: Select a layer. This is needed before changing layersettings. This layer is also used for drawing upon.

command.name: name
command.long: Set the name of the selected layer.

notes.note: First set active layer with setlayer

command.name: visible
command.long: Select if the selected layer/all layers is/are visible or not.

notes.note: First set active layer with setlayer

command.name: selectable
command.long: Select if the current layer/all layers is/are selectable or not.

notes.note: First set active layer with setlayer

command.name: bordercolor

syntax.simpara: r g and b are in [0..255]

command.long: Defines the border color of the selected layer. This determines color of the borders around polygons and the color of text.

notes.note: First set active layer with setlayer

command.name: fillcolor

syntax.simpara: r g and b are in [0..255]

command.long: Defines the fill color of the selected layer. This determines the color with which polygons are filled.

notes.note: First set active layer with setlayer

command.name: brush
command.long: Selects the fill pattern of the selected layer. This determines how polygons are filled on the screen.

notes.note: First set active layer with setlayer

command.name: viewstructure
command.long: Select a structure to make visible on the screen. All operations work on the visible structure.

notes.note: A file must be in memory, and the structure must be available.

command.name: drawoutline
command.long: Drawoutline sets the option to Draw-only the outlines of the drawing, i.e. not to fill the primitives.

notes.note: If the polygons are visible but not filled, check the fill- color and pattern.

command.name: showcoords
command.long: Select if the mouse coordinates are shown in the statusbar.

command.name: showgrid
command.long: Shows the grid on the screen using the gridsettings.

command.name: gridspace

syntax.simpara: <unit< in: pm, nm, um, mm, cm, dm, m, e, inch, ft

command.long: Specifies the distance between points, drawn as single pixels, horizontal and vertical.

notes.note: When showgrid is on, call draw, to draw grid with the new settings.

command.name: gridcolour
command.short: Specify the colour of grid points
command.long: Specifies the colour of gridpoints on the screen on white background.

notes.note: When showgrid is on, call draw to draw grid with the new settings.

command.name: gridplacement
command.short: Specify the place of the grid
command.long: Specifies the place of the grid. When this value is 0, the grid is drawn on the background. When 1, the grid is drawn on the foreground.

notes.note: When showgrid is on, call draw to draw grid with the new settings.

command.name: zoom
command.long: Zoom to the selected rectangle given in database units.

command.name: zoomback
command.long: Zoom to the previous zooming coordinates from the zoom history.

command.name: zoomout
command.long: Zoom to the first zooming coordinates in the zoom history, this selects full view of the current structure.

command.name: zoomout2
command.long: zoom out 2 times current size, enables to zoomout to extend beyond the boundingbox of the full drawing.

command.name: select
command.long: Selects elements (also references) in specified area or at given point. With point selection the elements are selected inside out (smallest first). In deselection mode this is the same.

command.name: clearscreen
command.long: Clearscreen fills the screen with color <rgb>.

command.name: draw
command.long: Clear the screen and then redraws the drawing.

command.name: print
command.long: Print what's on the screen.

command.name: startpoint
command.long: Sets the relative startpoint to the selected coordinates. Used for calculating distance with relative points.

command.name: relativepoint
command.long: Sets the relative endpoint to the selected coordinates. Used for calculating distance to startpoint. When a relative point is defined, the 'distance' dialog appears (if it's not on the screen already). The properties calculated are: dx, dy, distance between start and endpoints and the angle of the line between the points.

command.name: addfile
command.short: adds a file to the file history
command.long: This command adds a file to the file history. Maximum no. is 10 files, the 10th pushes out the 1st. added

command.name: pause
command.long: This function shows a dialog with a message. Pressing <Enter> continues processing. Pause without a text shows a default message.

example.simpara: pause "This is a great opportunity to get a cup of java!"

command.name: exit
command.long: Close data- and process-file(s) and exits program, usefull from a process file.
